sents.sent: The Red River Rebellion began near Fort Garry in 1869, where Louis Riel established a provisional government.

challenge: Historical name change - Fort Garry became Winnipeg in 1873

sents.sent: York was incorporated as the Town of York in 1793 and served as the capital of Upper Canada until 1834.

challenge: Historical name change - York became Toronto in 1834

sents.sent: The Rideau Canal was completed in Bytown in 1832, transforming the lumber town into a major transportation hub.

challenge: Historical name change - Bytown became Ottawa in 1855

sents.sent: Fort Edmonton was established by the Hudson's Bay Company in 1795 as a major trading post.
Fort Calgary was established in 1875 by the North-West Mounted Police at the confluence of the Bow and Elbow rivers.
Paul de Chomedey founded Ville-Marie in 1642 as a missionary settlement on the Island of Montreal.
The settlement known as Pile O'Bones in 1882 was renamed Regina in honor of Queen Victoria.
Prince Albert Settlement was established in 1866 by Reverend James Nisbet as a Presbyterian mission.
New Westminster was the capital of the Colony of British Columbia from 1859 until confederation.

challenge: Name unchanged but administrative status changed

sents.sent: Rupert's Land was a vast territory granted to the Hudson's Bay Company in 1670, covering much of northern Canada.

challenge: Historical territory - no longer exists as political entity

sents.sent: Upper Canada was established in 1791 as a British colony following the Constitutional Act.

challenge: Historical political entity - became Ontario in 1867

sents.sent: Lower Canada was created in 1791 and later became part of the Province of Canada before Confederation.

challenge: Historical political entity - became Quebec in 1867

sents.sent: Fort Rouge was a French trading post established in 1738 near the Red and Assiniboine rivers.

challenge: Historical fort - now a neighborhood in Winnipeg

sents.sent: Jacques Cartier visited the Iroquoian village of Hochelaga in 1535 on the site of present-day Montreal.

challenge: Indigenous settlement name - site became Montreal

sents.sent: Stadacona was an Iroquoian village visited by Jacques Cartier in 1535, located where Quebec City now stands.

challenge: Indigenous settlement name - site became Quebec City
